School of Chemistry and Pharmaceutical Sciences Guangxi Normal University Guilin 541004 China School of Chemistry and Pharmaceutical Sciences, Guangxi Normal University, Guilin 541004, China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. # The present address is Duan No.2 Senior High School, Hechi 730700, China. By employing a C 3-symmetric ligand, 3,3′,3′'-[1,3,5-benzenetriyltris- (carbonylimino)]tris-benzoic acid (H3L), three metal-organic frameworks formulated as {Na4[Zn3(L)2(µ 3-OH)(µ 2-OH)3]·3DMF}n (1), {[Ca2(L)(MeOH)2(DMF)3]·Cl}n (2) and [Sr2(L)(H2O)2(DMF)Cl]n (3) have been solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by IR, PXRD and X-ray single crystal diffraction analyses. Complex 1 features a 2D twofold interpenetrated structure in which the [Zn3(µ 3-OH)(µ 2-OH)3(CO2)3O3] subunit acts as a 6-connected node and the L3− ligand as a 3-connected node, exhibiting a binodal (3, 6)-connected topology with a {43}2{43.612} point symbol. Complex 2 shows a 2D double-layered structure, exhibiting a (3,6)-connected {43}2{46.66.83} topology based on a centrosymmetric tetranuclear [Ca4(CO2)6] subunit as a 6-connected node and the L3− ligand as a 3-connected node. Complex 3 exhibits an extended 3D framework with a {46}2{412.612.84} topology in which the centrosymmetric {Sr4(CO2)6 [(O^O)acylamide]2} subunit performs as an eight connected node and the L3− ligand as an unusual 4-connected node. Complex 1 is explored well as a catalyst for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides into cyclic carbonates under the reaction conditions of 70°C, 1 bar atmosphere and free solvent. The efficient catalytic ability of 1 perhaps attributes to the high density of Lewis acidic sites of Zn2+ and Lewis basic -NH- groups in 1. Beside the basic function, the -NH- group in 1 can also perform as hydrogen bond donor (HBD) for the activation of epoxide in the catalytic process. A plausible mechanism for synergistic catalysis is proposed for the cycloaddition reaction. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Acylamide-functionalized Metal-organic frameworks CO2 Cycloaddition reaction Synergistic catalysis Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) has been cited as the leading culprit in inducing average temperature increase of the global surface, rising sea level, ecosystem disturbance, ocean acidification and extermination of living species. Therefore, it is urgent to reduce the level of carbon dioxide emissions in the atmosphere. CO2 capture storage and conversion (CCSC) is currently the promising technology being performed to reduce carbon emissions [1–3]. As an important class of porous materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination networks (PCNs) have attracted a lot of attention over the past few decades [4–8]. They have exhibit potential applications in gas storage and separation, chemical sensing, drug delivery and catalysis due to their structural features of ordered and tunable architecture, high adsorption capacity and modifiable groups [9–13]. Their ultra-high porosity, crystallinity and functionalizable organic linkers with unique properties such as high surface area, high stability, open channels and permanent porosity also make them attractive for CCSC applications. Recently, numerous approaches have been developed to efficiently store and convert CO2 [14–16]. In particular, one of the most promising avenues for CO2 fixation is coupling with epoxides to form cyclic and polymeric carbonates, which are currently used as value-added chemicals in numerous applications, such as intermediates as electrolyte components in lithium ion batteries, petroleum products, polar aprotic solvents, and fine chemicals [17–21]. Although several MOFs have been explored as heterogeneous catalysts for chemical conversion of carbon dioxide, the catalytic processes usually depend on long reaction time, high temperature and/or pressure to achieve good reaction conversions [22–30]. These disadvantages restrict their applications for industrial production. It is very essential to construct more efficient MOFs for CO2 chemical conversion in order to lower the energy consumption and production costs. For the carbon dioxide cycloaddition reactions, it is generally considered that the synergistic effects of Lewis acid-base sites and the auxiliary effect of nucleophilic reagents from the catalysts are conducive to highly efficient CO2 fixation. Many studies prove that the high content of unsaturated metal coordination sites (Lewis acid) and accessible nitrogen-rich groups (Lewis base) in MOFs can improve the capture capacity for CO2 at room temperature, which is advantageous to increase the content of CO2 around the active sites and accelerate the reactive rate of CO2 transformation [31–38]. The metal ions with large ionic radii and high charge density, such as Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Ga3+, In3+, Ga3+, Zr4+ and rare earth metal (Ln3+), not only possess a versatile coordination numbers which would easily create unsaturated metal sites, but also have strong Lewis acidity which is popular for the high activity of unsaturated metal sites. The NH2, pyridyl, imidazole and acylamide groups are commonly introduced to modify MOFs’ function. However, the catalytic performance of MOFs is affected collaboratively by many factors. The big challenge is the low thermal, chemical, and solvent stability of MOFs, which is derived from the potentially reversible nature of coordination bonds and restricts their applications. The formation of interpenetrated structure can increase the stability of MOFs, but could induce low porosity. Furthermore, the metal ions with high positive charge can also increase the strength of coordination bonds and Lewis acidity [39–43]. Many well-known MOFs as UiO-66, MIL-101, ZIF-8, HKUST-1, VPI-100 and FJI-C10 have been extensionally explored for the carbon dioxide cycloaddition reactions [44–50]. MOFs’ catalysis can be modified by introducing functional group in their organic parts. Theoretical and experimental investigations have demonstrated that the amino group as hydrogen bond donors (HBD) in MOFs are favorable for the activation of epoxides and can improve the carbon dioxide binding affinity and uptake [51–55]. Considering the above-mentioned, the C3-symmetric ligand, 3,3′,3′'- [1,3,5-benzene- triyltris(carbonylimino)]trisbenzoic acid (H3L), is used to construct three architectures: {Na4 [Zn3(L)2(µ 3-OH)(µ 2-OH)3]·3DMF}n (1), { [Ca2(L-MeOH)2(DMF)3]·Cl}n (2), [Sr2(L)(H2O)2(DMF)Cl]n (3). They are prepared under solvothermal condition and characterized by IR, PXRD and single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. The catalysis of complex 1 for cycloaddition reaction of CO2 is explored under relatively mild conditions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Experimental 2.1.1 Materials and methods All reagents are obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Ligand 3,3′,3′'- [1,3,5-benzenetriyltris(car-bonylimino)]trisbenzoic acid (H3L) is prepared according to the literature. [56] FT-IR spectra are recorded as KBr pellets on a PerkinElmer FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000-450 cm−1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns are recorded at 293 K with Rigaku D/Max 2500 diffractometer at 40 kV, 100 mA with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation and 2θ ranging from 5 to 50°. SEM and EDS elemental mapping images are obtained with a field environmental scanning electron microscope (FESEM, Quanta 200 FEI) equipped with a Rontec EDS system. 1H NMR spectra are recorded in CDCl3 on Bruker Advance (400 MHz) instruments. The content of metal was detected by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, Perkin-Elmer NexION300). The synthesized ligand is determined by IR and 1H NMR (Fig. S1). 2.1.2 X-Ray diffraction analysis for Crystal structures Crystallographic data for complexes 1–3 are collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II with Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω and θ scan modes. All the structures are solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package. Hydrogen atoms are generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. Due to tiny or bad crystals, the data of X-ray single crystal diffraction are not better. Some large residual peaks are proposed to a highly disordered mix of solvents from the crystallization process, effectively as a non-crystalline frozen solution. The cation of Na+ in 1 is determined by energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) analysis (Fig. S2). For complexes 1-3, the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results are summarized in Table 1 . Selected bond distances and bond angles are listed in Table S1- S3. CCDC numbers for complexes 1–3 are 2160238-2160240. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. 2.2 Preparation of complexes 1–3 2.2.1 Synthesis of {Na4[Zn3(L)2(µ3-OH)(µ2-OH)3]·3DMF}n (1) ZnCl2(54.5mg, 0.4 mmol), H3L (56.7 mg, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in DMF/MeOH (3mL/2mL) in a 20-mL vial. The mixture was sonicated for 20 min and then heated for for 72 h in a 70°C isothermal oven, followed by cooling to room temperature. Colorless block crystals of Zn-MOF produced were washed with DMF/MeOH (3mL/2mL) and dried in air. (yield: 24.54% based on H3L) IR (KBr, ν/cm–1): 3440(br), 3260(br), 3072(br), 1668(s), 1621(m), 1581(s), 1553(w), 1489(w), 1442(m), 1398(s), 1317(m), 1289(m), 1262(m), 1233(w), 1171(w), 1099(m), 1001(w), 958(m), 910(m), 818(m), 770(s), 731(m), 676(s), 592(m) (Fig. S3). 2.2.2 Synthesis of {[Ca2(L)(MeOH)2(DMF)3]·Cl}n (2) The synthesis method of Ca-MOF is similar to that of Zn-MOF except that CaCl2 (44.4 mg, 0.4 mmol) was used instead of ZnCl2. Colourless block crystals of Ca-MOF were obtained in a 28.73% yield based on H3L. Colorless cone crystals of Sr-MOF thus produced were washed with DMF/MeOH (0.5mL/2mL) and dried in air. (yield: 24.54% based on H3L) IR (KBr, ν/cm–1): 3418(br), 3301(m), 3075(m), 1669(s), 1633(m), 1616(m), 1547(s), 1483(m), 1396(s), 1305(m), 1251(s), 1127(m), 1078(m), 1019(w), 913(m), 880(w), 827(m), 770(s), 746(m), 729(m), 688(m), 669(m), 591(m), 536(m) (Fig. S3). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural description of {Na4[Zn3(L)2(µ3-OH)(µ2-OH)3]·3DMF}n (1) Compound 1 crystallizes in the trigonal space group R3c. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Zn2+ ion, two different thirds L3− ligands, one μ 3-OH− and one μ 2-OH− ions, as well as one free DMF molecule (Fig. 1 a). In 1, three Zn2+ ions are interconnected via µ 3-OH and µ 2-OH units to form a [Zn3(µ 3-OH)(µ 2-OH)3] cluster which is further capped by six carboxyl groups from different L3− ligands, resulting in a [Zn3(µ 3-OH)(µ 2-OH)3(CO2)3O3] subunit (Fig. 1a). Each Zn2+ ion is coordinated by six O atoms respectively from three different L3− ligands, one μ 3-OH atom and two μ 2-OH atoms, constructing a slightly distorted ZnO6 pentagonal pyramid geometry. Two crystallographically independent L3- ligands in 1 exhibit different coordinating modes: the carboxyl groups in one L3− adopt a monodentate coordination mode (μ 1-η 1:η 0) and those in another L3− adopt a bidentate bridging mode (μ 2-η 1:η1 ) (Fig. S4). Adjacent three [Zn3(µ 3-OH)(µ 2-OH)3(CO2)3O3] subunits are interconnected by these two isolated L3− ligands, forming a 2D double-layered network (Fig. 1b and c). When the trinuclear Zn2+ subunit is considered as a 6-connected node and the L3− ligand as a 3-connected node, the 2D double-layered network can be simplified as a network with a 3,6-connected net topology with a {43}2{43.612} point symbol (Fig. 1d) [57]. Two such 2D networks are parallely intertwined into a twofold interpenetrated structure (Fig. 2 ) which is stabilized by π···π stacking interactions [58]. There are two kinds of π···π stacking interactions within the twofold interpenetrated structure (Fig. S5). One kind of π···π stacking interaction comes from the central phenyl groups of four ligands from different 2D networks, with the interplanar distance of 3.430(4) and 3.511(4) Å. Another kind of π···π stacking interaction comes from terminal phenyl groups of two ligands belonging to different 2D networks, with the interplanar centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.730(6) Å, and an interplanar distance of 3.459(4) Å. Furthermore, the interpenetrated 2D networks are packed in a staggered fashion with a –(ABCA´B´C´)n– repeating order (Fig. S6). The C-H⋯O interactions between neighboring interpenetrating networks make 2D networks into a 3D architecture (Fig. S7) [59]. 3.2 Structural description of {[Ca2(L)(MeOH)2(DMF)3]·Cl}n (2) Complex 2 crystallizes in the triclinic P1 space group. The asymmetric unit of 2 contains two crystallographically independent Ca2+ ions, one L3− ligand, two coordinated MeOH, three coordinated DMF and one uncombined Cl− ion (Fig. 3 a). Two isolated Ca2+ ions and their symmetry-related atoms are held together via the carboxylic groups from different L3− ligands to afford a centrosymmetric tetranuclear [Ca4(CO2)6] cluster subunit which exhibits a six-connected mode (Fig. S8). Each L3− ligand performs as a three-connected node to connect three adjacent [Ca4(CO2)6] subunits (Fig. S9), resulting in a 2D double-layered structure (Fig. 3b). Two independent Ca2+ ions display different coordination modes: Ca1 is eight-coordinated with six carboxylic O atoms from four different L3− ligands and two O atoms from different coordinated MeOH molecules, showing a distorted biaugmented trigonal prism with the Ca1-O bond distances running from 2.3311(17) to 2.5914(19) Å. Ca2 is coordinated by three carboxylic O atoms from different L3− ligands and three carbonyl O atoms from different DMF molecules, showing a six-coordinated octahedron geometry with the Ca2-O bond distances running from 2.2736(18) to 2.3313(2) Å. Each L3− ligand bridged seven Ca2+ ions, where three carboxylate groups exhibit different coordination modes: μ 2-η 1:η1, μ 2-η 1:η2, μ 3-η 1:η 2:η1 (Fig. S10). Adjacent 2D networks in 2 are reinforced via π···π and C-H···π interactions [45]. The offset π···π stacking interaction exists between the central phenyl group and terminal phenyl group in ligands respectively from different networks, with the centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.990 (17) Å (Fig. S11), and the interplanar distance is 3.394(11) Å. The C-H···π interaction exist between CH3 group in DMF to one nearest terminal phenyl group in ligand from adjacent network, with the C···π distance of 3.782(7) Å and 3.361(1) Å (Fig. S12). Topologically, when the tetranuclear Ca2+ cluster surrounded by six L3− ligands is simply regarded as a 6-connected node and the L3− ligand as a 3-connected node, the overall structure of the 2D network is best described as a 2-nodal 3,6-connected kgd topology with the Schläfli symbol {43}2{46.66.83} analyzed by Topos 5.0 program (Fig. 3c) [57]. 3.3 Structural description of [Sr2(L)(H2O)2(DMF)Cl]n (3) Complex 3 crystallizes in the triclinic P1 space group. The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Sr2+ ions, one fully deprotonated L3− ligand, one Cl− anion and one coordinated DMF (Fig. 4 a). Two independent Sr2+ ions and their symmetry-related atoms are held together via carboxylic oxygen atoms from six different L3− ligands and acylamide oxygen atom from another two different L3− ligands to afford a centrosymmetric {Sr4(CO2)6[(O^O)acylamide]2} cluster subunit (Fig. S13), while each L3− ligand connects these four adjacent [Sr4] cluster units (Fig. S14), resulting in the formation of a 3D framework (Fig. 4b). The Sr2+ ions reveal different coordination modes: Sr1 is coordinated by six carboxylic oxygen atoms from four different L3− ligands, one acylamide oxygen atom from another L3− ligand and one oxygen atom from coordinated DMF, adopting an eight-coordinated triangular dodecahedron geometry with the Sr1-O bond distances running from 2.468(4) to 2.802(3) Å. While Sr2 atom is eight-coordinated by four carboxylic oxygen atoms from three different L3− ligands, one acylamide oxygen atom from another L3− ligand, one Cl− ion and two coordination water molecules, exhibiting a triangular dodecahedron geometry with the Sr2-Cl bond distance of 3.0605(12) Å and the Sr2-O bond distances in the range of 2.516(3)–2.706(3) Å. In each L3− ligand, three deprotonated carboxyl groups adopt respectively one μ 3-η 1:η 2:η1 and two chelating bridging μ 2-η 1:η2 coordination modes, while each of two acylamide oxygen atoms coordinates to a different Sr atom (Fig. S15), making the L3− ligand evolve from a 3-connected node to a 4-connected node (Fig. 4c). Therefore, the 3D framework of 3 could be viewed as a (4,8)-connected flu topology with the Schläfli symbol of {46}2{412.612.84} by considering the L3− ligand as a four-connected node and the [Sr4] cluster as an eight connected node (Fig. 4c) [57]. In each L3− ligand, three deprotonated carboxyl groups adopt respectively one μ 3-η 1:η 2:η1 and two chelating bridging μ 2-η 1:η2 coordination modes, while each of two acylamide oxygen atoms coordinates to a different Sr atom (Fig. S15), making the L3− ligand evolve from a 3-connected node to a 4-connected node (Fig. 4c). Therefore, the 3D framework of 3 could be viewed as a (4,8)-connected flu topology with the Schläfli symbol of {46}2{412.612.84} by considering the L3− ligand as a four-connected node and the [Sr4] cluster as an eight connected node (Fig. 4c) [57]. The coordinated DMF and the lattice solvent molecules are located within the one-dimensional channels in the 3D network structure of complex 3 (Fig. S16). Interestingly, if the coordination of acylamide oxygen atoms is overlooked, ligand L3− could be regarded as a 3-connected node, resulting in the structure of 3 to be evolved into a classically (3,6)-connected network which is similar to that in complex 2. It is well known that the central metal ions play an essential role in the architectural design of the various structures. In this work, three coordination polymers based on L3− ligand and different metal centers (Zn2+, Ca2+ and Sr2+) have been synthesized under solvothermal condition, which display distinct coordination structures. These central metal ions belonging to the IIB/IIA groups with different radii exhibit different coordination numbers and have obvious effects on the coordination modes of L3− ligand and finally influence on the architectures of 1–3. For example, the Zn2+ ion in 1 shows the coordination number of 6, and the carboxylated groups in L3− ligand exhibit monodentate (μ 1-η 1:η 0) and bidentate bridging (μ 2-η 1:η 1) coordination modes, finally resulting in a 2-D twofold interpenetrated structure. In 2, two kinds of Ca2+ ions show different coordination numbers as 8 and 6, while groups in L3− ligand adopt bridging (μ 2-η 1:η 1) and chelating bridging (μ 2-η 1:η 2, μ 3-η 1:η 2:η 1) coordination modes, inducing a 2D double-layered framework formed. When Sr2+ ion was employed in complex 3, the coordination number of Sr2+ ion is 8, while the carboxylated groups in L3− ligand exhibit a chelating bridging (μ 2-η 1:η 2, μ 3-η 1:η 2:η 1) coordination mode. But two acylamide oxygen atoms in L3− participate in coordination, making the L3− ligand evolve from a 3-connected node to a 4-connected node for the formation of an extended 3D framework of 3. 4 Catalytic cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides Recently, the literatures indicate that Zn2+ centers in zinc-based MOFs could act as Lewis acidic sites for catalysis [60–62]. With this in mind, here we investigate the catalytic activity of 1 for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides to form cyclic carbonates. Before the catalytic reactions, the catalyst of 1 is activated by heating at 60°C for 12 h under vacuum condition after it is soaked in CH3OH for solvent exchange with three times. Styrene oxide (SO) is selected as a model substrate to assess the catalytic performance of 1 and to investigate optimized reaction conditions under solvent-free condition. Tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) was demonstrated to be more effective as a cocatalyst for this cycloaddition reaction than tetrabutylammonium chloride (TBAC), tetrabutylammonium iodide (TBAI), or KX (X = Cl, Br, I) [51,52]. Hence, all the following investigations were carried out with TBAB as a co-catalyst. The percent conversions are determined by 1H NMR. As can be seen from Table 2 , both 1 and TBAB show low activities when they are used alone (Table 2, entries 1 and 2). Observably, compound 1 combined with TBAB exhibits a significant catalytic activity at 87.72% styrene carbonate (SC) conversion with 70°C and 1 atm for 24 h (Table 2, entry 3). To optimize experimental parameters, the reactions are proceeded with different catalyst amount, temperatures and times. As depicted in Fig. S17a, the SO conversion enhanced with increasing amount of Zn-MOF catalyst up to 0.05 mmol (80 mg), the SO conversion could reach above 87.72%. Further increase in catalyst loading has no significant effect on the SO conversion. From the viewpoint of economy, 0.05 mmol catalysts were retained as the optimised loading in following reactions. The percent conversion of SC increases with the rise in temperature and time (Fig. S17b and S18). However, the conversions have a little change at higher than 70°C and longer than 24 h. Taking account of energy utilization, the optimized reaction conditions are therefore selected at 70°C and 1 atm for 24 h. In addition, after the removal of catalyst 1 at the time when the reaction is proceeded for 12 h, the substrate conversion is almost stopped, revealing that the catalyst has a significant influence on the catalytic reaction. To further evaluate the catalytic efficiency of 1, ligand H3L, metal salt ZnCl2 and the mixture of H3L and ZnCl2 are also selected respectively as a catalyst to proceed the same catalytic reaction. The corresponding percent conversions of SC are only 35.09%, 53.76% and 49.26%, respectively (Table 2, entries 4, 5 and 6). The good catalytic performance of 1 may be ascribed to the synergistic effect of active metal sites and -NH- functional groups [36,63]. To verify the cyclicity, catalyst 1 was reused five times for the catalytic reaction under identical conditions. The conversions of SC have a little decrease from 87.72% to 72.99% (Fig. S19). But catalyst 1 keeps the structural integrity after five cycles, affirmed by PXRD patterns (Fig. S20). In order to determine the Zn2+ leaching, the filtrate after the reaction was analyzed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) and only 1.268 ppb of leakage from the framework of catalyst 1 was found (Table S4). The slightly decrease of catalytic activity may be ascribed to the incomplete removal of SC absorbed on catalyst. The catalytic generality of 1 has also been examined by several typical epoxides for the cycloaddition reaction (Table 2, entries 7-10) under optimized reaction conditions. All the corresponding cyclic carbonates are obtained in comparatively excellent conversions (80-98%). The results clearly show that 1 can catalyze the cycloaddition reaction with relatively extensive epoxides. The relatively low conversions of larger size epoxide substrates can be mainly ascribed to the steric hindrance of the substituent groups that make the nucleophilic attack rate of Br− slow, and meanwhile retard the approach of the substrate towards the catalytic sites. However, the higher conversion of 1-chloro-2,3-epoxypropane than 1,2-epoxybutane (Table 2, entries 8 and 9) could be originated from the existence of an electron-withdrawing group of Cl which allows the breakage of the C–O bond of epoxide easier. Complex 2 exhibits structural instability after activation (Fig. S21). Its activated sample was used to explore the cycloaddition reaction of styrene oxide with CO2, giving the SO conversion of only 39.53% (Fig. S22). Furthermore, the synthesized 2 was also exploited to proceed this catalytic reaction without activation, and the SO conversion of 1st and 2nd cyclic experiments are 62.5% and 37.59% (Fig. S23 and S24), respectively, meaning that complex 2 would be destroyed after 1st cyclic reaction, which is also proved by the PXRD of 2 after the 1st cyclic experiment (Fig. S21). When complex 3 is selected as a catalyst to proceed the same catalytic reaction, the small size epoxides exhibite good product conversion ranging from 82–94% (Table 2, entries 11-14), while only 52.36% conversion for SO is observed under the identical conditions (Table 2, entry 14). The lower catalytic efficiency of 3 to SO can be attributed to its structural features. Briefly, the involvement of two acylamide oxygen atoms in coordination imparts steric hindrance of the large-sized substrate approaching the catalytically active sites in 3. It is worth comparing the efficiency of compound 1 with earlier reported MOFs for coupling CO2 into cyclic carbonates. As shown in Table S5, some of them mostly require harsh conditions (relatively high temperature and/or CO2 pressure). Notably, Compound 1/TBAB system displays comparable activity to some reported catalysts under mild conditions (70°C, 1.0 bar). The efficient catalysis of 1 perhaps attributes to the high density of Lewis acidic sites of Zn2+ and Lewis basic -NH- groups in 1. Beside the basic function, the -NH- group in 1 can also perform as hydrogen bond donor (HBD) for the activation of epoxide. 5 Tentative reaction mechanism A potential catalytic mechanism is proposed based on previous studies for the chemical fixation reaction of CO2 [52,34]. As shown in Fig. 5 , the cycloaddition reaction is initiated by the activation of epoxide ring, which is synergistically promoted by the polarization of epoxide from Lewis acidic site of Zn and the hydrogen bonding between epoxide and the -NH- functional group. Meanwhile, the Br− nucleophile from TBAB attacks the less-hindered and strong electrophilic carbon atom of the activated epoxide to assist the ring-opening process of epoxide. Finally, the intermediate is formed rapidly by the opened ring anion of epoxide with the surrounding CO2 molecule which have been attracted and activated by Lewis basic site of -NH- group to produce alkylcarbonate anion, and further converted into the corresponding cyclic carbonate through the cyclization step. Simultaneously, the catalyst regenerates for the next run. Hence, the introduction of -NH- group in 1 is believed to be more efficient activation of epoxide via formation of hydrogen bonds to initiate the cycloaddition reaction, leading to high catalytic activity for the chemical fixation of CO2 into cyclic carbonates under mild conditions. 6 Conclusions In summary, we have successfully synthesized three MOFs based on different metal ion of Zn2+, Ca2+ and Sr2+ and 3,3′,3′'-[1,3,5-benzenetriyltris(carbonylimino)]trisbenzoic acid. These three complexes display different structures as a twofold interpenetrated 2D structure of 1, a 2D double-layered structure of 2, and a 3D network structure of 3, which may be mainly resulted from the different radii of metal ions. Complex 1 is proven to be efficient as a heterogeneous catalyst for the cycloaddition of epoxides with CO2 into cyclic carbonates at 70°C and 1 bar of CO2 with free solvent. The synergistic catalysis of Lewis acidic Zn2+ ions and the Lewis basic -NH- groups could play an efficient role in the catalytic reaction. Despite the structural instability and steric hindrance, complex 2 and 3 are not explored completely for the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides with CO2, this might offer a new strategy to explore the synthesis of MOFs based on alkaline-earth metal could serve as a general protocol for developing more complexes for desired applications. coredata.dc:description: By employing a C 3-symmetric ligand, 3,3′,3′'-[1,3,5-benzenetriyltris- (carbonylimino)]tris-benzoic acid (H3L), three metal-organic frameworks formulated as {Na4[Zn3(L)2(µ 3-OH)(µ 2-OH)3]·3DMF}n (1), {[Ca2(L)(MeOH)2(DMF)3]·Cl}n (2) and [Sr2(L)(H2O)2(DMF)Cl]n (3) have been solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by IR, PXRD and X-ray single crystal diffraction analyses. Complex 1 features a 2D twofold interpenetrated structure in which the [Zn3(µ 3-OH)(µ 2-OH)3(CO2)3O3] subunit acts as a 6-connected node and the L3− ligand as a 3-connected node, exhibiting a binodal (3, 6)-connected topology with a {43}2{43.612} point symbol. Complex 2 shows a 2D double-layered structure, exhibiting a (3,6)-connected {43}2{46.66.83} topology based on a centrosymmetric tetranuclear [Ca4(CO2)6] subunit as a 6-connected node and the L3− ligand as a 3-connected node. Complex 3 exhibits an extended 3D framework with a {46}2{412.612.84} topology in which the centrosymmetric {Sr4(CO2)6 [(O^O)acylamide]2} subunit performs as an eight connected node and the L3− ligand as an unusual 4-connected node. Complex 1 is explored well as a catalyst for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides into cyclic carbonates under the reaction conditions of 70°C, 1 bar atmosphere and free solvent. The efficient catalytic ability of 1 perhaps attributes to the high density of Lewis acidic sites of Zn2+ and Lewis basic -NH- groups in 1. Beside the basic function, the -NH- group in 1 can also perform as hydrogen bond donor (HBD) for the activation of epoxide in the catalytic process. A plausible mechanism for synergistic catalysis is proposed for the cycloaddition reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Construction of Acylamide-functionalized MOFs for efficient catalysis on the conversion of CO2
